item.title: üìñ Conclusion: Adopting a feminist note-taking system
item.description: Notes are generally considered important (if dull) aspects of learning and research ( Gimenez & Pinel, 2013; Morehead et al, 2019; Tinny & Nhamo, 2013).

item.title: üìñ Developing a feminist note-taking system
item.description: Kit Chokly, PhD Student in Communication Studies, McGill University Table of contents On format Introduction Conceptualizing notes as…

item.title: üìñ Four principles of a feminist note-taking methodology
item.description: Considering the varying conceptualizations of notes as representations, constructions, and structures of knowledge in relation to feminist epistemological concerns, I return to my original question: How can we take notes committed to producing socially just knowledges?

item.title: üìñ Introduction
item.description: Most researchers write notes every day. This banality positions note-taking as practice requiring little explanation: We read something, attend a lecture, or make a research observation, and then commit it to paper (digital or otherwise), storing it for retrieval at a later date (or not).

item.title: üìñ Notes as constructions of knowledge
item.description: An exception to the concern for note accuracy stems from approaches which recognize the constitutive rather than representational role note-taking plays in the production of knowledge.

item.title: üìñ Notes as representations of knowledge
item.description: Most of the literature on note-taking focuses on writing individual notes on a particular topic, usually with an emphasis on their use as memory aids.

item.title: üìñ Notes as structures of knowledge
item.description: Whether understood as materializations of memory or the process of situated thought itself, notes do not stand alone: They are always in relation to other thoughts, ideas, and observations.

item.title: üìñ On format
item.description: The strength of a feminist note-taking system, as I will come to argue, is its networked qualities‚Äîa strength that is not necessarily shared with essays or linear arguements.

item.title: üìñ Principle of atomicity
item.description: Write notes to include only one idea Establishing a networked note-taking system requires reconceptualizing what makes up a note. Primarily, we are concerned here with notes which contain ideas: Notes on other types of information such as biographical data or shopping lists are not necessarily the most useful within the network (although biographical data can be usefully linked to particular ideas as a form of citation, as this digital paper strives to demonstrate).

item.title: üìñ Principle of flatness
item.description: Store notes in one container Whether working on a computer or on paper, typical file structures rely on folders and subfolders to organize information.

item.title: üìñ Principle of interconnection
item.description: Link notes liberally Refusing to rely on containers or long-winded details to organize and contextualize our notes means we must instead turn to the use of other notes to function in these capacities.

item.title: üìñ Principle of iteration
item.description: Review and re-evaluate notes periodically The last principle of a networked note-taking system is the principle of iteration. A note is not necessarily complete once it is written.

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è 4 Principles of a feminist networked note-taking system
item.description: Granularity Flatness Interconnection Iteration [!quote]- Transcript Drawing on principles from networked note-taking, the following are four guidelines I use to inform my own feminist note-taking methodology.

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è 4. Iteration
item.description: Review notes and re-evaluate periodically Make them more or less granular Develop new connections between notes and sources Next: Conclusion

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Agenda
item.description: [!tip]Follow along kitchokly.github.io/quartz Framing note-taking Notes as representations of knowledge Notes as constructions of knowledge Notes as structures of knowledge Towards feminist networked note-taking 4 Principles of a feminist networked note-taking system Granularity Flatness Interconnection Iteration Conclusion [!

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Conclusion
item.description: Note-taking has always been a research method Understanding note-taking as a feminist method encourages us to think about‚Ä¶ how we represent sources what we consider note-worthy how we bring ideas into relation to produce knowledge There is no one-size-fits-all networked note-taking system These 4 principles are only a guideline A good system should be flexible to work with your needs Next: Works cited

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Feminist networked note-taking?
item.description: Feminist approached to information organization E.g., feminist approaches to archives Also part of the construction of knowledge How can we treat note-taking with intention, as a legitimate part of our research methods informed not just by representation and perspective, but also¬†the systems which put notes in conversation with each other?

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Feminist networked note-taking?
item.description: Feminist approached to information organization E.g., feminist approaches to archives Also part of the construction of knowledge How can we treat note-taking with intention, as a legitimate part of our research methods informed not just by representation and perspective, but also¬†the systems which put notes in conversation with each other?

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Flatness
item.description: Storing notes in one container Prevents duplicate work Scales with the system Encourages connection Notes are retrieved primarily through contextual relations Finding notes based on the way they link to other notes (see Interconnection) Digital search and metadata can be helpful to find specific content if needed Next: Interconnection

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Framing note-taking (1/3)
item.description: Notes as representations of knowledge Considered a part of other methods Understands notes as representational Used to inform subsequent analysis Next: Notes as constructions of knowledge

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Framing note-taking (2/3)
item.description: Feminist concerns with representation What is considered note-worthy? Feminist emphasis on subjectivity in knowledge production Standpoint theory ( Hartsock, 1985) Sitpoint theory ( Garland-Thomson, 2002) Situated knowledges ( Haraway, 1988) Notes are always subjective and connected to context Next: Notes as structures of knowledge

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Framing note-taking (3/3)
item.description: Notes as structures of knowledge Personal Knowledge Management (PKM) [!info] Networked notetaking Finding ways to make connections within and between the variety of notes we take.

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Granularity
item.description: Writing notes to only include one idea Should include the source of the idea Also known as atomicity ( Tietze, 2013) It‚Äôs difficult to draw boundaries around a note/idea If it‚Äôs too granular, the note doesn‚Äôt stand on its own If it‚Äôs not granular enough, it‚Äôs harder to make connections between ideas Reviewing and revising helps find the sweet spot (see 4.

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Interconnection
item.description: Linking notes liberally is the core of the system Uses relations between notes to find, organize, and contextualize them Treats research as a process of relationship-building Next: Iteration

item.title: üìΩÔ∏è Note-taking as an interdisciplinary feminist method
item.description: McGill Feminist Research Colloquium, April 13, 2023 | Kit Chokly, PhD Student in Communication Studies Two of the author‚Äôs milk crates stuffed full of notebooks, file folders, and envelopes.
